choices.B: There is no stateful egress rule in the security list associated with the public subnet
choices.A: The route table has no default route for routing traffic to the internet gateway
choices.D: There is no stateful ingress rule in the security list associated with the public subnet
choices.C: There is no dynamic routing gateway (DRG) associated with the VCN

discussion.content: It's A and B, it's not necessary DRG for internet connectivity. DRG is for peering, VPN and Fastconnect
A & B, default route for IG, & Stateful Egress rule needed.

A & D 
Why do we need egress stateful rule? If it is stateful then it won't be egress.

A)
Each public subnet that needs to use the internet gateway must have a route table rule that specifies the gateway as the target.
Aunque tenga un RT asociado la subnet si este no tiene una regla referente al IG no va a poder salir.
A y B seg√∫n la pagina.

B)
The gateway supports connections initiated from within the VCN (egress) and connections initiated from the internet (ingress).

NOT D)
Despite being true, the question ask only about out connection to internet (egress)
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Tasks/managingIGs.htm

comments.content: In "None can reach the internet" I understand requesting internet URLs and not receiving an answer, so it would be ingress traffic. So I guess answer is A and D

questions.question_text:
You have created a public subnet and an internet gateway in your virtual cloud network (VCN). The public subnet has an associated route table and security list.
However, after creating several compute instances in the public subnet, none can reach the Internet.
Which two are possible reasons for the connectivity issue? (Choose two.)
Which two choices are true for Autonomous Data Warehouse (ADW)? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Billing for compute stops when ADW is stopped
choices.A: Billing stops only when the ADW is terminated
choices.B: Billing stops for both CPU usage and storage usage when ADW is stopped
choices.D: Billing for storage continues when ADW is stopped

discussion.content: Update, correct answer is C, D
Answer is CD.
C and d

CD
https://www.oracle.com/database/technologies/datawarehouse-bigdata/adb-faqs.html#MANAGING-BOOKMARK

What is the minimum compute requirement for Oracle Autonomous Database?
One OCPU is required to do any work, but the compute portion of the service instance can be turned off and billing for compute will be halted. Billing for storage continues as long as the service instance exists.

Reference
https://www.oracle.com/database/technologies/datawarehouse-bigdata/adb-faqs.html
A and C is the correct answer

questions.question_text:
You have created a virtual cloud network (VCN) with three private subnets. Two of the subnets contain application servers and the third subnet contains a DB
System. The application requires a shared file system so you have provisioned one using the file storage service (FSS). You also created the corresponding mount target in one of the application subnets. The VCN security lists are properly configured so that both application servers and the DB System can access the file system. The security team determines that the DB System should have read-only access to the file system.
What change would you make to satisfy this requirement?

choices.A: Create an NFS export option that allows READ_ONLY access where the source is the CIDR range of the DB System subnet.
choices.C: Modify the security list associated with the subnet where the mount target resides. Change the ingress rules corresponding to the DB System subnet to be stateless.
choices.B: Connect via SSH to one of the application servers where the file system has been mounted. Use the Unix command chmod to change permissions on the file system directory, allowing the database user read-only access.
choices.D: Create an instance principal for the DB System. Write an Identity and Access Management (IAM) policy that allows the instance principal read-only access to the file storage service.

discussion.content: A is ans
A is the Correct answer, NFS_Export

Selected Answer: D
NFS export (A) is partially correct because creating an NFS export option that allows READ_ONLY access would restrict access to the file system based on the source CIDR range of the DB System subnet. However, it is not the most secure option because it relies on IP-based access control, which can be less secure than access control based on identity and access management (IAM) policies.

Therefore, the most secure and appropriate option is to create an instance principal for the DB System and write an IAM policy that allows the instance principal read-only access to the file storage service. This approach provides fine-grained control over access to the file system based on the identity of the DB System, ensuring that only the DB System can access the file system and only for read-only operations.
Correct answer is A

choices.A: Create a group for developers on OCI and map the group to a similar group in Microsoft Active Directory during the federation process.
choices.B: Federate all Microsoft Active Directory groups with OCI to allow users to use their existing credentials.
choices.D: Create a group for developers on OCI, export all the developers from Microsoft Active Directory, and then import them into the Identity and Access Management (IAM) group.
choices.C: Create a new user account for each user, and then create policies to provide access to developers.

discussion.content: I reckon it's A too. B is the least correct answer, it'll let everyone have access. C isn't wrong, but isn't the right way to do it. Not sure if D will work out.
Correct option is A. https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Identity/Tasks/federatingADFS.htm
